author: Authors Gideon Forman Climate Change; Transportation Policy Analyst Other Articles
title: Meet the man behind Canadaâ€™s leading renewable energy co-op - David Suzuki Foundation
text: Chris Caners, general manager of Torontoâ€™s [Solar Share](https://solarbonds.ca/) renewable energy co-operative, is talking to me about solar powerâ€™s many virtues. He smiles and his whole face comes to life. He clearly loves this technology. â€œSolar is an amazing electricity generation mechanism because you can literally do it anywhere,â€ he says. â€œSo, you avoid things like transmission losses because â€¦ youâ€™re generating the power where youâ€™re consuming it.â€ He also speaks with exuberance about solarâ€™s affordability. When he joined Solar Share in 2016, solar was 75 cents per watt. Now itâ€™s closer to 30 cents â€“ less than half. â€œSo, itâ€™s pretty incredible,â€ he says. Caners explains that research and development and mass production in China are key factors in solarâ€™s cost reduction. Heâ€™s looked at the price of various energy sources and has no hesitation saying that â€œindustrial solar and wind â€” the big, big solar and wind â€” are the cheapest by quite a ways.â€ The cost of solar is lower but itâ€™s also stabler. â€œYou donâ€™t have the volatility of operational cost like [with other] fuels,â€ Caners says. â€œIf we have to rely on uranium or gas or coalâ€¦ those are international markets or continental markets, and the prices go up and down. Whereas for solar, you know, it lasts for 25 years and thereâ€™s no fuel for it other than the sun.â€ The cost of solar is lower but itâ€™s also stabler. â€œYou donâ€™t have the volatility of operational cost like [with other] fuels,â€ Caners says. â€œIf we have to rely on uranium or gas or coalâ€¦ those are international markets or continental markets, and the prices go up and down. Whereas for solar, you know, it lasts for 25 years and thereâ€™s no fuel for it other than the sun.â€ Solar Share was founded in 2010 and now owns and operates more than 50 solar energy projects in Ontario. It raises capital by selling â€œsolar bondsâ€ to Ontarians â€” at a minimum of $1,000 each â€” that pay a fixed interest rate, typically three to five per cent a year. The co-op has some $80 million in investments. (Full transparency: Iâ€™m a member myself!) Playing devilâ€™s advocate, I ask Caners if organizations like his can operate on a scale sufficient to address the climate crisis. Solar Share is one of the countryâ€™s largest renewable co-ops, yet it has only about 2,000 members. Caners says thereâ€™s no reason in principle why co-ops must be small and, with supportive government policy, they could become large, powerful organizations. â€œIt is possible for co-ops to scale [up]; and if we look at places around the world where cooperatives have been successful, I think youâ€™ll see [they] had to have â€¦ support from government. But they can certainly be huge players.â€ He cites, in particular, the huge number of co-ops in Germany. â€œIt is very common for German citizens to be part of an energy co-op and to buy their electricity from co-ops,â€ he says. Of course, this large group of residents profiting from renewables is a powerful voting block that can protect these projects from hostile governments â€” a crucial lesson for us in Canada. If we want wind and solar to thrive, we need to ensure the benefits of these power sources accrue to many people. If we want wind and solar to thrive, we need to ensure the benefits of these power sources accrue to many people. Those benefits include local employment. Caners tells me solar energy creates a whole array of good jobs, some of them not immediately obvious. â€œ[Consider] project development. Well, thereâ€™s a lot of work in trying to find suitable sites for solar. You need to have people who are going and talking to people to find land and do interconnection,â€ he says. â€œThen thereâ€™s all the [work] once you get a site and you have the agreement of the landlords and neighbours. Then you have the engineering, procurement and construction. So thatâ€™s a huge number of jobs. Once thatâ€™s done, then we have operations and maintenance [on the solar panels].â€ Our conversation turns to the federal governmentâ€™s proposed clean electricity regulations, which, over time, will largely end gas- and coal-fired power generation. The David Suzuki Foundation believes the phase-out can be accomplished by 2035 but some politicians are skeptical. Whatâ€™s Canersâ€™ view? Beyond the mid-2030s do we need fossils on the grid? â€œItâ€™s clear that we donâ€™t. Weâ€™ve seen lots of examples. California is generating all of its power over time from 100 per cent renewables. Theyâ€™re huge and theyâ€™ve done it. Costa Rica has done it. I believe the U.K., even for different periods of time, has done it. â€¦ I remember 20 or 30 years ago people saying â€˜Oh, thereâ€™s no way we can put more solar on the grid than 15 per cent or 10 per cent. Itâ€™s just not possible.â€™ Okay, well it is possible. I donâ€™t buy the argument that we canâ€™t do it.â€ â€œItâ€™s clear that we donâ€™t. Weâ€™ve seen lots of examples. California is generating all of its power over time from 100 per cent renewables. Theyâ€™re huge and theyâ€™ve done it. Costa Rica has done it. I believe the U.K., even for different periods of time, has done it. â€¦ I remember 20 or 30 years ago people saying â€˜Oh, thereâ€™s no way we can put more solar on the grid than 15 per cent or 10 per cent. Itâ€™s just not possible.â€™ Okay, well it is possible. I donâ€™t buy the argument that we canâ€™t do it.â€ As our conversation draws to a conclusion, I ask Caners whatâ€™s next for his organization. He says heâ€™d like the co-op to participate in something called â€œvirtual net metering.â€ â€œSo right now, we canâ€™t set up a solar project and sell our power to you,â€ he says. â€œWe can just sell our electricity to the government. What we want to do is be able to set up a solar project and then sell the kilowatt hours to people who want to buy kilowatt hours from Solar Share. â€¦ I think that would be very exciting and it would allow us to deploy more solar. Iâ€™d love that! Virtual net metering is the thing that Iâ€™m probably most keen on as a path forward.â€ Related Projects Always grounded in sound evidence, the David Suzuki Foundation empowers people to take action in their communities on the environmental challenges we collectively face.

title: La Aemet da la fecha en la que llega un nuevo frente de lluvias a EspaÃ±a: estas son las zonas afectadas
text: La Aemet da la fecha en la que llega un nuevo frente de lluvias a EspaÃ±a: estas son las zonas afectadas A lo largo de este fin de semana, se producirÃ¡ un gran cambio en el tiempo de nuestro paÃ­s por la entrada de una borrasca por el AtlÃ¡ntico [Jorge Rey advierte del cambio drÃ¡stico de tiempo en los prÃ³ximos dÃ­as: bajada de temperaturas y posibilidad de granizo](https://www.abc.es/recreo/jorge-rey-advierte-cambio-drastico-tiempo-proximos-20240510172850-nt.html) [Mario Picazo da la fecha de la llegada de lluvias a EspaÃ±a y lanza una alerta por las temperaturas: Â«Por encima de la mediaÂ»](https://www.abc.es/recreo/mario-picazo-fecha-llegada-lluvias-espana-lanza-20240507121204-nt.html) El calor ha sido la tÃ³nica de estos Ãºltimos dÃ­as en gran parte de EspaÃ±a y asÃ­ seguirÃ¡ durante las prÃ³ximas horas. Durante estas jornadas, las [temperaturas mÃ¡ximas](https://www.abc.es/sociedad/aemet-avisa-brusca-subida-temperaturas-grados-partir-20240506053000-nt.html) serÃ¡n Â«mÃ¡s propias del mes de junioÂ», con termÃ³metros que podrÃ­an superar los 30ÂºC en algunos puntos de EspaÃ±a, aunque el buen tiempo no durarÃ¡ eternamente, segÃºn ha advertido la Agencia Estatal de MeteorologÃ­a (Aemet) en un comunicado. A lo largo de este fin de semana, llegarÃ¡ un gran [cambio en el tiempo](https://www.abc.es/sociedad/aemet-avisa-regreso-lluvias-espana-despues-alcanzar-20240508053000-nt.html#mrfhud=true) a nuestro paÃ­s. La situaciÃ³n anticiclÃ³nica que se ha impuesto estos dÃ­as darÃ¡ paso a un nuevo episodio de lluvias y tormentas en algunas regiones del paÃ­s a partir del domingo 12 de mayo, cuando aumentarÃ¡ esta inestabilidad y las [temperaturas altÃ­simas](https://www.abc.es/espana/madrid/cambio-radical-tiempo-madrid-aemet-alerta-altas-temperaturas-fin-semana-20240507183845-nt.html) del viernes y el sÃ¡bado descenderÃ¡n en muchos puntos con el paso de una masa de aire frÃ­o. ðŸ—£ï¸ El meteorÃ³logo JosÃ© Miguel ViÃ±as advierte: pronto volverÃ¡n lasâ€” Meteored | tiempo.com (@MeteoredES) [#lluvias]â˜” a EspaÃ±a, el [#calor]serÃ¡ intenso pero durarÃ¡ poco. ðŸ“‰ âž¡ï¸ Todos los detalles con [@Divulgameteo]. [https://t.co/pEF18mNCAy] [pic.twitter.com/OZHetYlQ5F] [May 8, 2024] Nueva subida de las temperaturas este fin de semana El ambiente veraniego se ha impuesto en EspaÃ±a con el paso de un anticiclÃ³n que ha dejado un tiempo seco y caluroso en casi todo el paÃ­s. En las Ãºltimas horas, los termÃ³metros han ascendido bruscamente hasta dejar temperaturas por encima de los 30 grados en los valles del Guadiana, Tajo y tambiÃ©n en el Ebro y por encima de los 25ÂºC en el resto de la PenÃ­nsula. La semana serÃ¡ mÃ¡s cÃ¡lida de lo normal en el paÃ­s, con Â«temperaturas propias de junioÂ» el viernes 10 y el sÃ¡bado 11 de mayo. En capitales de provincia como Zaragoza, Toledo, Ciudad Real, Madrid, CÃ¡ceres, Badajoz, Sevilla, CÃ³rdoba y JaÃ©n se podrÃ­a alcanzar los 30ÂºC, mientras que en el suroeste peninsular incluso podrÃ­an superarse los 35ÂºC. ðŸŒ¡ï¸â¬†ï¸ Las temperaturas suben durante los prÃ³ximos dÃ­as: se superarÃ¡n los 30, e incluso los 32 ÂºC, en zonas del sur y del centro de la PenÃ­nsula. TambiÃ©n en Ã¡reas del nordeste y en Canarias.â€” AEMET (@AEMET_Esp) Es posible que entre el domingo y el lunes se inicie una bajada de las temperaturas. [pic.twitter.com/nE6X0dJst5] [May 7, 2024] Los termÃ³metros continuarÃ¡n su escalada en gran parte de la mitad norte peninsular. SegÃºn la Aemet, este fin de semana tambiÃ©n subirÃ¡n las mÃ­nimas en muchas zonas de EspaÃ±a, aunque las amplitudes tÃ©rmicas entre temperaturas mÃ­nimas y mÃ¡ximas podrÃ­an alcanzar los 20 grados en algunas localidades. Un frente atlÃ¡ntico trae lluvias y un descenso en las temperaturas A partir del sÃ¡bado, se espera que las altas presiones de estos Ãºltimos dÃ­as vayan desplazÃ¡ndose, permitiendo la entrada de nuevos frentes de lluvias provenientes del AtlÃ¡ntico a lo largo del fin de semana. Durante esta jornada, podrÃ­an volver las precipitaciones al noroeste peninsular, con chubascos generalizados en Galicia y el CantÃ¡brico. Â¿QuÃ© se espera este fin de semana?â€” AEMET (@AEMET_Esp) â˜”ï¸ Chubascos generalizados, el sÃ¡bado en el noroeste peninsular y el domingo en el noreste. ðŸŒ¡ï¸ Temperaturas mÃ¡s propias de mes de junio. PrÃ³xima semana: seguirÃ¡n las precipitaciones en el norte peninsular con bajada notable de temperaturas. [pic.twitter.com/wDTuuWHRYr] [May 9, 2024] El domingo se notarÃ¡ mÃ¡s este cambio, pues la entrada de aire frÃ­o por el norte podrÃ­a venir acompaÃ±ada de nuevas tormentas que irÃ¡n avanzando de oeste a este, afectando al tercio norte peninsular. AdemÃ¡s de la zona cantÃ¡brica, podrÃ­amos ver lluvias localmente intensas en CataluÃ±a, AragÃ³n y PaÃ­s Vasco, ademÃ¡s de algunas localidades del interior peninsular. Junto con este nuevo frente de lluvias que llega a EspaÃ±a vendrÃ¡ tambiÃ©n una masa de aire frÃ­a, que provocarÃ¡ una intensa bajada en las temperaturas de cara a la prÃ³xima semana. En el norte de la PenÃ­nsula se despedirÃ¡n momentÃ¡neamente del calor durante estos primeros dÃ­as.

author: Dale Anderson News Staff Reporter
title: Dennis P. Farrell, 73, banker and volunteer who found joy in helping people
text: Dennis Farrell had a 44-year career in banking, but it wasnâ€™t money that attracted him to the world of finance. â€œHe was in it for the people,â€ his son Michael said, â€œfor the comradery and for the opportunity to offer other people opportunities. It also was an opportunity to wear really nice ties.â€ In retirement, he became a Eucharistic minister in hospitals and did other volunteering for the same reasons. â€œHe treated his volunteer work like a job ... in a good way,â€ his son said. â€œHe took it very seriously. People always remarked about how well-dressed he was. They thought he was a doctor.â€ He pursued a full schedule of volunteer work until shortly before his unexpected death Dec. 28 in Strong Memorial Hospital, Rochester. He was 73. Born in Buffalo, the second of 11 children, Dennis Patrick Farrell was the son of Neil and Ella Collins Farrell. His father owned and operated Farrellâ€™s Dairy in South Buffalo and was the subject of a chapter in Tim Russertâ€™s book, â€œWisdom of Our Fathers: Lessons and Letters from Daughters and Sons.â€ He attended St. Teresaâ€™s School, was a 1968 graduate of what was then Bishop Timon High School and earned a bachelorâ€™s degree in American history from Canisius College, now Canisius University. While attending college, Mr. Farrell took a job at Liberty Bank, and became a teller. For a while he also wrote an employee newsletter, which led him to interview Jeane McFillin, who worked at another branch. They were married in 1972. Mr. Farrell joined Bank of New York the following year and held various branch positions. In the late 1970s, he became a branch manager in South Buffalo. He went to the former Marine Midland Bank in 1981 and managed branches in Hamburg and Williamsville. When it became HSBC Bank, he continued with the company as a commercial credit officer, district executive and regional credit executive. After Mr. Farrell retired in 2012, he threw himself into volunteering, assisting at the St. Vincent de Paul Society, St. Lukeâ€™s Mission of Mercy, the Response to Love Center and Meals on Wheels. Inspired by the examples of two of his aunts, who were Sisters of Mercy, he became a Eucharistic minister at Mercy Hospital in South Buffalo, Sisters Hospital and Buffalo General Medical Center, chatting with patients and offering Communion several days a week. He took masterâ€™s degree classes in pastoral studies and counseling. â€œHe would talk to anybody about anything,â€ his son Michael said. â€œHe was always interested in peopleâ€™s backgrounds and he would go out of his way to remember things about their lives.â€ A longtime Hamburg resident, he was active in a series of Catholic parishes as a lector and religious educator, including St. Ambrose, Our Lady of Perpetual Help, SS. Peter and Paul in Hamburg, St. Francis of Assisi, St. Mary of the Lake and St. John Paul II. â€œAs a family,â€ his son said, â€œwe were notorious church-hoppers.â€ At St. Ambrose in 1986, Mr. Farrell and his wife were among families who hosted children from Colombia for a year. When their guestâ€™s orphanage closed, he stayed on and they legally adopted him. Mr. Farrell later visited Bogota and befriended several members of his adopted sonâ€™s extended family. Proud of his Irish heritage, Mr. Farrell displayed a large shamrock on his home and, as a member of the Blackthorn Club, marched every year in Buffaloâ€™s St. Patrickâ€™s Day Parade. He was a devoted fan of the Buffalo Bills and Notre Dame football and enjoyed literature, film and music, ranging from Nat King Cole to the Clancy Brothers. In addition to his wife, who worked at Wanakah Landscaping and Lockwoodâ€™s Greenhouses in Hamburg, survivors include two sons, Alfredo and Michael; two daughters, Katharine Bair and Mary Cullinane; four brothers, Tim, Neil, Joseph and Martin; five sisters, Mary Farrell, Joanne Oscadal, Colleen Holman, Maureen Farrell and Patricia Farrell; and eight grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial was offered Jan. 4 in St. John Paul II Church, Lakeview. Email [danderson@buffnews.com](mailto:danderson@buffnews.com).

author: Sanjana Dubey
title: Spainâ€™s Unparalleled Destination: CÃ³rdobaâ€™s October Weather Reaches A Stunning 27Â°C
text:
The Andalusian region in Spain boasts numerous stunning destinations, each one captivating enough to enchant visitors.
Seville is famous for its vibrant energy and breathtaking architecture, while Malaga offers stunning beaches, a wealth of cultural experiences, and a lively nightlife. Granada features the iconic Alhambra, a spectacular palace and fortress celebrated as one of the most significant examples of Islamic architecture.
However, amidst this remarkable collection of cities lies CÃ³rdobaâ€”a delightful destination that frequently goes unnoticed.
CÃ³rdoba, recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, boasts a deep historical legacy, with its origins tracing back to Roman times in 152 BC. Visitors can still explore traces of its rich past throughout the city today.
In the 10th century, CÃ³rdoba served as the capital of the Moorish Empire during the â€˜Islamic Golden Age.â€™ During this period, the city thrived as a hub for art, science, and philosophy, establishing itself as one of the most sophisticated cities in Europe.
Today, CÃ³rdoba is frequently overlooked in favor of more famous Andalusian locations. However, those who venture here will discover breathtaking architecture and a vibrant cultural landscape, featuring the impressive Mezquita-Cathedral, the historic Roman bridge, and the charming alleys of the Jewish quarter.
CÃ³rdoba has even earned a spot in Skyscannerâ€™s annual list of the most sought-after destinations for 2025.
It ranked fifth among locations that have experienced the most significant rise in searches in the past year, joining other remarkable places like TromsÃ¸ in Norway and Siem Reap in Cambodia.
While weâ€™ve already highlighted CÃ³rdobaâ€™s appeal, hereâ€™s everything you should know before you finalize your travel plans to this Andalusian gem.
Getting to CÃ³rdoba: Your Travel Guide
The closest airport to CÃ³rdoba is in Seville, approximately 130 kilometers (81 miles) southwest of the city.
From Seville, travelers have various options for reaching CÃ³rdoba. Renting a car allows for a scenic drive of about 90 minutes. Alternatively, a direct train ride takes between 45 minutes to an hour.
Several airlines, including Ryanair, EasyJet, and British Airways, offer direct flights from London to Seville. The flight duration is roughly two hours and 45 minutes, with ticket prices starting at around Â£45 in late October, according to Skyscanner.
Another option is to fly into Malaga Airport, located about 165 kilometers (103 miles) from CÃ³rdoba. Direct flights from London to Malaga take approximately two hours and 40 minutes and can be more budget-friendly, with fares starting at just Â£20 in October, according to Skyscanner.
The journey from Malaga to CÃ³rdoba is comparable in time; driving takes around one hour and 45 minutes, while direct train services cover the distance in roughly 50 minutes.
CÃ³rdobaâ€™s Climate: What to Expect
The ideal time to visit CÃ³rdoba is in the spring (April to early June) or during the autumn months (September to October), when the weather is mild and perfect for exploring the city in comfort.
As an inland city in southern Spain, CÃ³rdoba experiences more intense temperatures compared to coastal regions, with its summers often reaching scorching and uncomfortable levels.
For this reason, itâ€™s best to avoid visiting between July and August, as temperatures often climb above 40Â°C.
October is an excellent alternative, offering cooler but still warm weather, with temperatures reaching up to 27Â°Câ€”ideal for those looking to soak up some late-season sun.
Winter in CÃ³rdoba is also enjoyable, with mild temperatures ranging from 10-16Â°C and fewer tourists, making it perfect for those seeking a quieter experience away from the crowds.
Top Things to Do in CÃ³rdoba
CÃ³rdoba, with its UNESCO World Heritage designation, is rich in history and culture, offering countless attractions for visitors.
No trip to the city would be complete without exploring the Mezquita Cathedral, hailed by Lonely Planet as one of the â€œworldâ€™s most remarkable examples of Islamic architecture.â€
Initially constructed as a mosque in the 8th century, the Mezquita was transformed into a Christian cathedral in the 13th century.
It showcases distinctive horseshoe arches with red and white stripes, a prayer hall adorned with carved columns, and an exquisitely designed mihrab.
With over 23,300 reviews on Tripadvisor, the Mezquita boasts a five-star rating, with visitors frequently describing it as â€œmagnificent.â€
CÃ³rdoba is also home to numerous Roman landmarks, with the most striking being the Roman Bridge of CÃ³rdoba. Initially constructed in the 1st century BC during the reign of Emperor Augustus, it remains an iconic symbol of the cityâ€™s ancient history.
Though it has seen numerous renovations throughout its history, much of the Roman Bridgeâ€™s original structure remains preserved. Visitors on Tripadvisor have praised it as both â€œmarvelousâ€ and â€œfascinating,â€ highlighting its timeless appeal.
